header_summary:
Peter Todd introduces an analysis of cryptocurrency transaction security, specifically addressing the efficiency of potential attacks on transactions utilizing the full-RBF (Replace-By-Fee) mining strategy. He highlights how the cost-effectiveness of such attacks largely depends on the fee rate of the attacking transactions and the proportion of miners adopting full-RBF. This insight underscores the complexity of miner incentives and transaction fees in safeguarding cryptocurrency integrity. Further exploration of Todd's findings can be found on his [website](https://petertodd.org).

In a separate discussion, /dev /fd0 sheds light on the challenges Bitcoin developers face in preserving transaction privacy, introducing Octojoin as a novel solution aimed at complicating on-chain analysis by mimicking an octopus's ability to blend in. Octojoin enhances privacy through a technique that involves combining multiple inputs from different users into a single transaction, making it difficult for third parties to trace ownership. This approach not only improves transaction privacy but also encourages the use of swaps and the sale of statecoins derived from coinjoined UTXOs. Detailed information about Octojoin and its privacy-enhancing capabilities is available at [https://octojoin.github.io/](https://octojoin.github.io/).

recent_posts.title: A "Free" Relay Attack Taking Advantage of The Lack of Full-RBF In Core
recent_posts.summary:
- Peter Todd examines a potential attack on cryptocurrency transactions focusing on mining aspects.
- He explains that the cost efficiency of attacks is not affected by hash power for full-RBF mining until a fee threshold is met.
- Beyond this threshold, attack cost efficiency linearly increases with the percentage of full-RBF miners.

recent_posts.title: Octojoin: Payjoin with no interaction between sender and recipient
recent_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin developers face challenges in maintaining transaction privacy.
- Octojoin is proposed to enhance privacy by blending transactions seamlessly.
- Feedback is encouraged to refine Octojoin, with details available on its official page.

active_posts.title: Great Consensus Cleanup Revival
active_posts.summary:
- Antoine Poinsot highlighted the Great Consensus Cleanup on DelvingBitcoin.org.
- He proposes restricting legacy transaction sizes and addressing the timewarp bug.
- Poinsot invites community feedback to enhance the Bitcoin consensus mechanism.

active_posts.title: Proposing a P2QRH BIP towards a quantum resistant soft fork
active_posts.summary:
- The proposal calls for quantum-resilient Bitcoin via a new signature algorithm to counter quantum threats.
- It introduces the "QuBit" soft fork as part of a series to protect Bitcoin from quantum vulnerabilities.
- Stakeholders are urged to review and contribute to the draft for proactive development and secure Bitcoin.

active_posts.title: BIP Draft: "ChillDKG: Distributed Key Generation for FROST"
active_posts.summary:
- Jonas, Nick, and Tim draft a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal focusing on FROST Threshold Signatures.
- Their draft, available on GitHub, solicits community feedback, with several development aspects pending.
- The proposal includes designing a separate BIP for FROST signing, currently under development by others.

active_posts.title: Segwit Ephemeral Anchors
active_posts.summary:
- Ephemeral Anchors allow for "dusty" values in key-less outputs, depending on Bitcoin's script system.
- The vulnerability to transaction ID malleability challenges integration with protocols like splicing.
- A proposed solution replaces "OP_TRUE" with "OP_TRUE 0xffff," leveraging bip141 to add only 3 bytes.

active_posts.title: Ephemeral Anchors and MEVil
active_posts.summary:
- An anomaly in blockchain's "anti-MEVil" mechanism allows manipulation of transaction order by increasing anchor value.
- Bob uses Alice's funds to conflict another transaction, illustrated by a detailed flowchart of four transactions.
- The motivation to manipulate arises from anti-DoS rules, leading to unforeseen issues in transaction validation.

active_posts.title: Stable Channels - peer-to-peer dollar balances on Lightning
active_posts.summary:
- Stable Channels integrates bitcoin-backed dollar balances with the Lightning network for stability.
- The project pairs BTC shorts seeking fiat stability with BTC longs, avoiding centralized stablecoin risks.
- It aims for decentralized financial stability on bitcoin, facing operational challenges while exploring innovations like Cashu integration.

today_in_history_posts.title: Covenant opcode proposal OP_CONSTRAINDESTINATION (an alternative to OP_CTV)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A new opcode, OP_CONSTRAINDESTINATION, aims to limit output destination addresses for step-wise covenants.
- It offers more flexibility compared to OP_CHECKTEMPLATEVERIFY, allowing outputs to merge like normal transactions.
- Feedback on the proposal, available on Github, is invited to enhance its presentation and identify any overlooked issues.

today_in_history_posts.title: Turbo channels spec?
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- A new proposal for `funding_locked_tlvs` allows earlier sending without features, requiring trust or sole funding.
- The sender must set `short_channel_id` for route hints and re-transmit if it changes, while receivers can ignore mismatches.
- Nodes can use channels immediately by sending `funding_locked` with fake or real `short_channel_id` after mining.

today_in_history_posts.title: Thoughts on scaling and consensus changes (2023)
today_in_history_posts.summary:
- Bitcoin's scalability involves establishing 50,000 off-chain "bitcoin banks" for user transactions.
- These entities aim to balance transaction costs with security, avoiding the blockchain's high fees.
- A hybrid system with sound Layer 2 protocols and security measures is crucial for scalability and integrity.
